description: From Middle English biten, from Old English bƒ´tan (‚Äúbite‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *bƒ´tan, from Proto-Germanic *bƒ´tanƒÖ (‚Äúbite‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *b ∞eyd- (‚Äúsplit‚Äù).

Cognates include Saterland Frisian biete (‚Äúbite‚Äù), West Frisian bite (‚Äúbite‚Äù), Dutch bijten (‚Äúbite‚Äù), German Low German bieten (‚Äúbite‚Äù), German bei√üen, beissen (‚Äúbite‚Äù), Danish bide (‚Äúbite‚Äù), Swedish bita (‚Äúbite‚Äù), Norwegian Bokm√•l bite (‚Äúbite‚Äù), Norwegian Nynorsk bita (‚Äúbite‚Äù), Icelandic b√≠ta (‚Äúbite‚Äù), Gothic êå±êå¥êåπêçÑêå∞êåΩ (beitan, ‚Äúbite‚Äù), Latin find≈ç (‚Äúsplit‚Äù), Ancient Greek œÜŒµŒØŒ¥ŒøŒºŒ±Œπ (phe√≠domai), Sanskrit ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç (bhid, ‚Äúbreak‚Äù).

entries.meaning: The act of biting.
The wound left behind after having been bitten.
examples: That snake bite really hurts!

entries.meaning: The swelling of one's skin caused by an insect's mouthparts or sting.
examples: Synonym: sting
After just one night in the jungle I was covered with mosquito bites.

entries.meaning: A piece of food of a size that would be produced by biting; a mouthful.
examples: There were only a few bites left on the plate.

entries.meaning: (slang) Something unpleasant.
examples: That's really a bite!

entries.meaning: (slang) An act of plagiarism.
examples: That song is a bite of my song!

entries.meaning: A small meal or snack.
examples: I'll have a quick bite to quiet my stomach until dinner.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) aggression
The hold which the short end of a lever has upon the thing to be lifted, or the hold which one part of a machine has upon another.
(colloquial, dated) A cheat; a trick; a fraud.
examples: The baser methods of getting money by fraud and bite, by deceiving and overreaching.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, dated, slang) A sharper; one who cheats.
(printing) A blank on the edge or corner of a page, owing to a portion of the frisket, or something else, intervening between the type and paper.
(slang) A cut, a proportion of profits; an amount of money.
(television) Ellipsis of sound bite.
examples: cold open: Starting a TV newscast with video or a bite from the lead story rather than starting with the anchor or the standard show open.

verbs.description: bite (third-person singular simple present bites, present participle biting, simple past bit, past participle bitten or (rare) bit)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut into something by clamping the teeth.
examples: As soon as you bite that sandwich, you'll know how good it is.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hold something by clamping one's teeth.
(intransitive) To attack with the teeth.
examples: That dog is about to bite!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To behave aggressively; to reject advances.
examples: If you see me, come and say hello. I don't bite.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take hold; to establish firm contact with.
examples: I needed snow chains to make the tires bite.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have significant effect, often negative.
examples: For homeowners with adjustable rate mortgages, rising interest will really bite.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a fish) To bite a baited hook or other lure and thus be caught.
examples: Are the fish biting today?

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To accept something offered, often secretly or deceptively, to cause some action by the acceptor.
examples: I've planted the story. Do you think they'll bite?

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive, of an insect) To sting.
examples: These mosquitoes are really biting today!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cause a smarting sensation; to have a property which causes such a sensation; to be pungent.
examples: It bites like pepper or mustard.

entries.meaning: (transitive, sometimes figurative) To cause sharp pain or damage to; to hurt or injure.
examples: Pepper bites the mouth.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cause sharp pain; to produce anguish; to hurt or injure; to have the property of so doing.
(intransitive) To take or keep a firm hold.
examples: The anchor bites.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take hold of; to hold fast; to adhere to.
examples: The anchor bites the ground.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To lack quality; to be worthy of derision; to suck.
examples: This music really bites.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal, vulgar) To perform oral sex on. Used in invective.
examples: You don't like that I sat on your car? Bite me.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, African-American Vernacular, slang) To plagiarize, to imitate.
examples: He always be biting my moves.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To deceive or defraud; to take in.
